government  and  aid  agency  initiatives  for  regional  economic 
cooperation.

substantial  economic  cost  to  the  country.  Completing  the

priority to better use existing road infrastructure.

1. 

Introduction 

 
The  transport  system  in  Bangladesh  is  extensive  and  diversified,  comprising  about 
2. 
140,000 kilometers (km)  of  roads,  2,700  km  of  railroads,  5,970  km  of  perennial  and  seasonal 
waterways,  two  major  seaports,  and  seven  airports.  The  primary  road  network  connecting 
national and regional roads and district roads comprises 20,800 km,1 while the secondary roads 
total 115,000 km. National and regional roads and district roads are administered by the Roads 
and  Highways  Department  (RHD)  within  the  Ministry  of  Communications  (MOC).  Secondary 
roads  are  administered  by  the  Local  Government  Engineering  Department  (LGED)  within the 
local government division. 
 
3. 
The  performance  of  the  road  sector  has  consistently  improved  in  the  past  decades, 
aided by extension of the road network and demand for road transport that increased rapidly at 
an average annual rate of 8.4% for passengers and 8.2% for freight during the 1990s, or almost 
double  the  average  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  of  4.7%.  The  modal  share  of 
transport  has  gradually  shifted  in  favor  of  roads.  From  1975  to  1997  the  modal  share  of  road 
transport rose from 54% to 73% for passenger traffic, and from 35% to 63% for freight. Roads 
have become the principal mode of transport.  
 
4. 
Roads  are  important  for  regional  cooperation,  which  constitutes  ADB’s  long-term 
development  strategy.  At  the  center  of  the  South  Asia  growth  quadrangle  and  surrounded  by 
India,  Nepal,  Bhutan,  and  Myanmar,  Bangladesh  will  accommodate  most  intraregional  transit 
shipments  in  the  region.  Asian  Highways,  conceived  and  pursued  by  the  United  Nations 
Economic and Social Commission for Asia and Pacific (ESCAP) to set up a road network linking 
Asia  and  Europe,  will  pass  through  Bangladesh,  making  it  the  link  between  South  and 
Southeast Asia. ADB’s assistance for the road sector in Bangladesh should foster a conducive 
environment for regional cooperation and maximize the development impact over South Asia.

RHD was founded in 1962, with 5,000 personnel, and 1,150 km of paved road under its

engineer who reports directly to the chief engineer.  
 
7. 
RHD has achieved its mission successfully, completing the five strategic road corridors 
with the assistance of aid agencies. However, RHD now needs to be restructured as the nature 
of its road works has changed substantially:  
 

(i) 

RHD  road  works  have  become  more  complex  and  sophisticated,  i.e.,  planning 
now  requires  more  advanced  techniques,  bridge  design  and  construction  are

becoming  more  complex,  and  pressure  is  greater  to  improve  the  quality  of  all 
works; 

(ii)  With the major road network now almost complete, the emphasis of RHD’s work 
moves  from  construction  to  maintenance,  which  is  not  technically  complex  but 
requires a high level of planning and management; and

10. 
RHD’s  road  network  is  estimated  at  $7.4  billion.  Annual  preventive  maintenance  is 
estimated  to  cost  $100  million.3  Actual  spending,  however,  is  around  $44  million,  with  the

its focus from road development to road maintenance. Under IDC3, RHD developed an annual 
road  maintenance  plan  (ARMP),  which  uses  the  highway  design  and  maintenance  standards 
model (HDM) to determine which roads should be maintained for the year and at what level.  
 
11. 
Strengthening institutional focus on road maintenance will, however, have only a limited 
effect unless additional sources of road maintenance financing are established. For the past 5 
years,  no  more  than  20–25%  of  road  sector  revenue4  has  been  spent  to  maintain  RHD  and 
LGED  roads.  NLTP  urges  the  establishment  of  a  sustainable  funding  mechanism  for  road 
maintenance by earmarking part of the fuel tax levy or introducing an additional road fuel levy. 
The  Government  plans  to  eliminate  backlog  maintenance  in  20  years  and  to  create  no  more 
once a sustainable funding mechanism is in place.  
 
12. 
Apart from finding a sustainable financing mechanism for road maintenance, continuing 
attention was paid to the shortfall of government resources for periodic road maintenance and 
the  increasing  backlog  of  deferred  maintenance.  The  World  Bank  provided  $70  million  for 
periodic  maintenance  over  2000–2004  through  its  Road  Rehabilitation  and  Maintenance 
Project.  ADB’s  past  two  road  projects  attempted  to  reduce  the  increasing  backlog  by 
encouraging  the  Government  to  commit  more  of  its  annual  budget  to  periodic  road 
maintenance.  ADB  allocated  $15.8  million  for  periodic  road  maintenance  and  required  the 
Government  to  pay  70%  of  the  cost  of periodic maintenance carried out through the projects, 
which  will  enable  the  Government  to  source  $47  million  to  finance  500  km  of  periodic 
maintenance for 5 years.

13. 
The fatality rate on the road network remains the highest in South Asia, with the number

identify hazards on new and existing roads.

established a consultative group that meets regularly in Dhaka, and increasingly seek to finance 
elements of a common sector agenda. For example, the main aid agencies’ support for IDC3’s 
institutional and road maintenance initiatives culminated in the development of NLTP.

73. 
The  project  benefits  are  wide-ranging  and  include  direct  and  quantifiable  benefits

74. 
The project roads’ economic internal rate of return (EIRR) ranges from 17.0% to 43.1%, 
or a combined EIRR of 26.2%. A review of the various factors affecting EIRR indicates that the 
main  threat  to  the  investment’s  viability  is  premature  road  failure  due  to  inadequate 
maintenance. The Project will help the Government establish and implement policies to mitigate 
these risks. Various sensitivity tests indicate that EIRR is robust in relation to construction cost 
increase by 15%, reduction of benefits by 15%, project implementation delay by a year, and a 
less-than-optimal maintenance after construction. The switching values of these sensitivity tests 
range from 33% to 98%. Detailed economic analysis for the road improvement components is in 
Appendix 13.

MAIN THRUSTS OF NATIONAL LAND TRANSPORT POLICY 

 
1. 
Private Sector Participation. In Bangladesh, the Government provides most transport 
infrastructure.  The  national  land  transport  policy  (NLTP)  encourages  the  private  sector  to 
participate  in  infrastructure  development  by  introducing  finance,  efficient  operating  techniques, 
and technological innovation. In accordance with the loan covenant of ADB’s Road Maintenance 
and Improvement Project, approved in 2002, the Government prepared the draft guidelines for 
private  investment  in  highway  projects  and  draft  laws,  which  are  now  under  review  by  various 
stakeholders.  
 
2. 
User Pays. In Bangladesh, roads are considered public goods, and the concept of “user 
pays”  for  road  infrastructure  is  not  well  accepted.  This  perception  has  long  been  a  critical 
obstacle to development of toll roads. The Government recognizes that transport users should 
pay  for  transport  facilities  provided  by  either  the  public  or  private  sector.  NLTP  ensures  that 
users  pay  for  the  costs  of  the  transport  operation  and  maintenance.  As  part  of  the  long-term 
highway plan, the Government will draw up plans for national toll roads with the consideration of 
establishing a separate authority and executive to deliver the toll road network.  
 
3. 
NLTP  spells  out  strategic  objectives  for  the  road  sector  formulated  in  line  with  policy 
dialogues carried out by ADB as well as by other aid agencies, which  (i) clarifying government 
responsibilities  for  roads  and  highways,  (ii)  introducing  long-term  network  planning,  (iii) 
maintaining the road network at a level which protects the value of the investment, (iv) securing 
a sustainable means of funding road expenditure, and (v) improving organizational efficiency of 
Roads and Highways Department (RHD).  
 
4. 
Roads and Highways Department and Local Government Engineering Department. 
The ownership of, and responsibility for, parts of the road network has not been so clear. RHD 
constructs  and  maintains  roads  as  does  Local  Government  Engineering  Department (LGED). 
Local  authorities  also  construct  some  roads.  RHD  and  LGED  thus  compete  for  ownership  of 
roads that are politically sensitive while simply neglecting others. NLTP ensures a logical split of 
responsibilities  between  RHD  and  LGED.  The  division  of  responsibilities  among  RHD,  LGED, 
and local authorities will be clearer and more rational. A committee to clarify road ownership has 
reclassified  existing  roads  and  reassigned  ownership  and  responsibility  between  RHD  and 
LGED for their development and maintenance.  
 
5. 
Long-Term  Network  Planning.  Provision  of  transport  infrastructure  needs  a  long 
planning  horizon.  NLTP  will  develop  a  long-term  (20-year)  road  master  plan  to  complete  the 
strategic  highway  network—roads  that  serve  strategic  business  and  commercial  centers.  This 
plan  will  be  evaluated  to  determine  priorities  for  construction  that  meet  economic  targets,  and 
will identify opportunities for private sector participation.  
 
6. 
Road Maintenance  and  Sustainable  Financing.  Most  resources  have  been  used  to 
build  new  roads  rather  than  to  maintain  highways.  This  imbalance  in  capital  and  revenue 
expenditure should be redressed to protect the value of road investment. NLTP seeks to avoid 
recurrence of backlog of road maintenance through improved routine and periodic maintenance. 
The  private  sector  will  be  encouraged  to  play  a  greater  part  in  highway  maintenance.  The 
Government has also started to research the most appropriate form of sustainable funding  for 
routine and periodic road maintenance. Whatever institutional arrangements are made to secure 
a  funding  source  for  maintenance,  NLTP  well  recognizes  that  government  revenues  are 
insufficient  to  address  the  problem.  For  sustainable  financing,  NLTP  will  set  aside  part  of  the 
fuel tax levy or consider the introduction of an additional road fuel levy.

PERFORMANCE-BASED MAINTENANCE CONTRACT 

Concept 

 
A. 
 
A  performance-based  maintenance  contract  is  an  agreement  between  a  government 
1. 
department or state enterprise and a private contractor whereby the private contractor maintains 
the road to achieve specified condition standards for a certain period (usually long term, ranging 
from 3 to 10 years) in return for a fixed payment stream. 
 
2. 
The concept of a performance-based contract originated from a consideration of (i) the 
increasing lack of personnel within the  government department to measure the vast quantity of 
activities  involved  in  the  more  traditional  maintenance  contracts,  and  to  monitor  performance 
standards using input indicators; (ii) the frequency of claims resulting from the need to increase 
the  quantity  of  activities  in  the  original  contracts;  (iii)  the  need  to  focus  more  on  customer 
satisfaction; and (iv) the need to shift greater responsibility to contractors throughout the entire 
contract period, as well as to stimulate and profit from their innovative capabilities.1 
 
3. 
The  performance-based  contract  is  different  from  a  traditional  quantity-  and  unit-price-
based,  short-term  maintenance  contract.  In  the  traditional  maintenance  contract,  the  private 
sector maintains an existing road based on input indicators, such as materials, equipment, and 
labor, and, more frequently, tons of pothole patch material used, number of linear meters of pipe 
culverts  replaced,  and  number  of  square  meters  of  crack  sealed.  In  the  performance-based 
contract,  the  private  sector  maintains  an  existing  road  on  the  basis  of  customer-based 
performance indicators, such as riding and strength quality (smoothness), safety features, and 
aesthetic and attractiveness of the roadside. 
 
4.

maintenance  concession.  Under  the  performance-based  contract,  performance  risks  are 
allocated between the government or client and the contractor. However, the traffic risk remains

The low-lying area at the mouth of the Ganges is also susceptible to tidal waves, cyclones, and tornadoes. 
The  severity  of  natural  disasters  is  exacerbated  by  the  precarious  nature  of  many  dwellings  lining  rivers 
and the coast.  
 
Bangladesh  suffers  from  some  of  the world’s highest malnutrition levels and thus worst health problems: 
childhood  protein-energy  deficiency,  maternal  undernutrition,  short  stature  and  anemia  in  expectant  and 
nursing  mothers,  and  micronutrient  deficiencies  affecting  all  ages.  In  1996–97,  more  than  half  of  all 
children under 5 were moderately or severely underweight, or suffering from moderate or severe stunting. 
Medical  facilities are scarce in Bangladesh and dominated by the public sector, which provides more than 
90%  of  the  country’s  health  services.  In  1999  there  was  one  hospital  bed  for  4,128  persons,  1  physician 
for  4,524  persons,  and  1  nurse  for  7,547  persons.  Access  to  health  services  is  more  restricted  than  in 
Pakistan  and  India.  Spending  on  healthcare  and  family  planning  hovered  around  1%  of  gross domestic 
product (GDP) in 1993–1998, and government health spending per person is around $3.60 annually. The 
literacy  rate  (over  7  years  of  age)  is  around  50%  in  2000,  and  the  adult  literacy  rate  is  about  60%.  Large 
disparities between urban and rural, and male and female literacy rates remain. 
 
The  agricultural  sector  is  the  s  largest  employer  and  accounts  for  approximately  60%  of  the  labor  force. 
Bangladesh  has  an  area  of  about  14  million  hectares ,  of  which  two  thirds  are  under  cultivation.  Over  the 
years,  population  growth,  urbanization,  and  erosion  have  reduced  the  amount  of  land  under  cultivation. 
Approximately  5%  of  farm  households  own  and  operate  about  one  quarter  of  all  agricultural  land. 
Agricultural land is highly fragmented due to population growth and traditional inheritance laws. The issue 
of  landlessness  is  of  particular  importance.  Economic  pressures  exacerbate  this  problem  by  forcing 
individuals  to  sell  the  entirety  of  any  remaining  landholdings  to  pay  off  debt  or  in  response  to  unforeseen 
events,  such  as  natural  disasters  or  the  death  of  household  heads.  Two  concepts  of  landlessness  are 
commonly  used.  One  is  complete  landlessness,  where  an  individual  does  not  have  any  land,  not  even  a 
homestead.  According  to  1999  Bangladesh  Bureau  of  Statistics  data,  approximately  10.2%  of  rural 
households  are  completely  landless.  The  second  definition  of  landlessness  refers  to  the  functionally 
landless, i.e., those owning land up to 0.2 hectare, inclusive of both cultivable and homestead land. Those 
classified  as  functionally  landless  account  for  53%  of  households.  Both  these  groups  survive  largely  on 
daily wages and, to some extent, on petty trading.

Selection  of  Project  Regions  and  Roads.  Poverty  was  a  major  criterion  for  selecting

Project Design and Implementation. Road design takes into account innovative alignment 
and  pavement  design  to  accommodate  poor  people’s  common  transport.  The  design  provides 
wider,  harder,  and  paved  shoulders,  facilitating  nonmotorized  traffic  (NMT)  where  operators  and 
passengers are mostly poor. The design will enhance the speed of NMT per hour, and driving and 
riding  comfort,  as  well  as  reduce  road  accidents.  Pro-poor  construction  methods  will  be  used, 
particularly  in  earthwork,  embankment  construction,  local  material  procurement,  pavement

semiskilled  workers  in  the  project  area  during  and  after  construction.  The  Project  will  employ  a 
sizable number of laborers from neighboring areas, increasing poor households’ income, which, in 
turn, will help circulate more money. The Project will create more jobs in the NMT and MT sectors. 
Construction  of  project  roads  will  require  skilled,  semiskilled,  and  unskilled  laborers.  Road 
maintenance will create more jobs. Unskilled labor will be paid Tk539 million, and semiskilled labor, 
Tk221 million. The total wage bill for road improvement will be Tk876 million, including payments to 
skilled laborers. The project design ensures that goods and services will be procured in a manner 
that will benefit local suppliers. Project design also ensures gender equity. The Government will fix 
employment targets for women in construction works. Construction contracts will not allow different

Distribution of Benefits between Owners/Operators and Clients/Passengers. The share 
of  distribution  to  different  beneficiaries  depends  on  several  assumptions.  If  the  situation  is 
competitive for all vehicle categories on all roads after improvement, and free entry and exit are 
common  on  all  roads,  then  distribution  can  be  expected  to  be  fair  and  just.  If  the  situation  is 
monopolistic,  then  owners  will  get  the  lion’s  share  and  little  will  be  left  for  clients  or  other 
beneficiaries.  However,  when  a  road  is  improved  in  Bangladesh,  traffic  starts  pouring  in 
immediately, inducing growing competition in the market. Price undercutting is often observed. Fair 
competition can be assumed to continue after road improvement.  
 
7. 
Passenger vehicle categories are (i) buses (large, medium-sized, mini, micro); (ii) cars, utility 
vehicles,  and  motorcycles;  (iii)  auto -tempos  and  baby  taxis;  and  (iv)  cycle  rickshaws/vans.  How

8.    Only  the  nonpoor  can  afford  cars,  utility  vehicles,  and  motorcycles,  and  thus  all  benefits 
accruing to them go to the nonpoor. Two types of bus service are available: (i) low-cost, economy 
buses  serving  short  distances  within  the  district  or  region;  and  (ii)  luxury  services  serving  usually 
long -distance intercity routes. The first is a major traffic category in the project roads. The market for 
economy bus service is open and competitive but route permits are regulated by the Bangladesh

passengers  in  other  forms:  lagging  fare  increases  in  response  to  general  increase  in  input  costs, 
undercutting rates for over loaded passengers, etc. Around 60-70% of VOC savings are eventually 
passed on to the passengers.

Rickshaws and vans are common modes of rural and urban transport. The market is highly 
competitive  and  market  entry  or  exit  is  free,  even  in  towns.  Municipal  authorities  encourage 
rickshaw operators/pullers to register for a nominal fee. Typically the vehicles are owned by small 
businesspeople and rented out daily to pullers in towns and cities. In rural areas, however, half the 
owners  are  operators/pullers  themselves.  Standard  fares  are  usually  determined  by  forces  of 
demand and supply. In cities and towns the fare increases when the weather is bad and during peak

reducing  wear  and  tear  on  vehicles  and  reduced  maintenance  costs.  Rickshaw  pullers  will gain 
because they will be able to go faster with less effort and make more trips. Passengers will gain 
from lower fares and faster speeds. About 80% of savings were estimated to accrue to passengers.

and  maintaining  a  safe  distance  between  the  asphalt  plant  and  public  facilities,  including
